title: Fork Oil Renew - Refilling

body.body: The oil level is measured from the upper surface of the fork outer tube, with the fork fully compressed and the spring and spring spacer removed.
Fork Oil Level (spring, spring seat and spacer removed, and the fork fully compressed)
upper surface of the fork top cap flange  is 55.7 mm above the lower surface of the upper yoke
Fill the fork with the grade of oil specified in the fork oil level chart, to a level above that which will finally be required.

Pump the fork assembly and damper several times to expel any trapped air then fully compress the fork and support it in an upright position. Leave the fork for a few minutes to allow the oil to stabilise.
to the level specified (see the fork oil table or illustration below for the correct level setting).

Zero level on the tool is set at the small exit hole in the side of the scale tube, NOT AT THE END TIP. Do not attempt to block this side hole as this will cause the final fluid level to be incorrect.
Insert the scale end of the tool into the fork inner tube.

Hold the tool adjuster plate level with the upper surface of the fork inner tube and draw fluid into the syringe until fluid flow ceases (empty the syringe if the body becomes full before fluid flow stops).
The fluid level in the fork is now set to the height set on the tool scale. Check the tool scale setting and repeat the process if incorrectly set.
Incorrect fork oil levels could result in an unsafe riding condition leading to loss of motorcycle control and an accident.
Position the fork assembly as for compression of the fork spring during disassembly.
Fit the fork spring in the orientation noted for disassembly.
Fit the spring spacer, nylon spacer and the bump rubber.

If removed, the damping rod lock nut must be fitted with the flat face facing to the top of the fork. The slightly tapered face must face the fork spring. Incorrect orientation may lead to a loosening of the lock nut.
Turn the damper rod lock nut until the length of threads to the end of the rod is equal to the length measured during disassembly.
to the threads of the damper rod and pull the damper upwards.

While compressing the fork spring and while the spring holder is in place always wear protective equipment for the face and eyes and never stand directly above or look directly down on the fork. If the spring compressor or holder should dislodge or detach, the resulting release of spring tension could cause parts to fly off resulting in injury to the user.
as previously described. Compress the fork spring and refit the spring holder.
Inspect the O-ring for the top cap for any damage, replace if necessary.
Carefully install the top cap and rebound adjuster rod. Slowly turn the cap until it touches the locknut.
and tighten the damper rod locknut to

While compressing the fork spring and while the spring holder is in place always wear protective equipment for the face and eyes and never stand directly above or look directly down on the fork. If the spring compressor or holder should dislodge or detach, the resulting release of spring tension could cause parts to fly off resulting in injury to the user.
Compress the spring to remove the spring holder.
Lubricate the O-ring on the top cap with a smear of fork oil then screw the top cap fully into the outer tube.
It is much easier to tighten the top cap when the fork has been refitted.
